title: Synthetic Recap
body:
CHICAGO (AP) – It was not a matter of if, but how. On a night when the offense struggled and the Indiana Pacers pushed, the Chicago Bulls had the ultimate answer: Michael Jordan.

His Airness delivered a performance for the ages, pouring in a staggering 45 points to single-handedly carry the Bulls to a hard-fought 104-96 victory. In a game where the team’s famed offensive machine sputtered, Jordan became the engine, the fuel, and the entire destination.

The Pacers, resilient and determined, hung around by committee. Rik Smits provided a strong interior presence with 20 points, while Derrick McKey and Dale Davis controlled the glass. But they had no counter for the singular force wearing number 23. Every Indiana run was met with a cold, calculated response from Jordan—a silky jumper from the wing, a relentless drive through traffic, an and-one finish that silenced the challengers.

While Scottie Pippen contributed a vital 16 points and Dennis Rodman corralled 15 rebounds, this night was a monument to one man’s will. The rest of the Bulls combined for a mere 43 points, a statistic that only magnifies the historic nature of Jordan’s 45-point masterpiece. He didn't just lead the offense; he *was* the offense.

In the crucible of the 1997 season, with the league gunning for the throne, this was a definitive statement. It was a game that stripped basketball down to its essence: give the ball to the greatest player on the planet and get out of the way. The Chicago Bulls did just that, and Michael Jordan, once again, lifted them on his shoulders and carried them home.
